revision.comment: Link to existing article on BizKid$
revision.text:
{{Infobox person |name = John Keister |image = |caption = |birth_name = |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1956|2|15}} |birth_place = [[Seattle]], [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]], [[United States|U.S.]] |death_date = |death_place = |death_cause = |alma mater = [[University of Washington]] |education = [[Franklin High School (Washington)|Franklin High School]], 1974 |residence = |other_names = |employer = [[KING-TV]], [[KIRO-TV]],
[[The Art Institute of Seattle|Art Institute of Seattle]] |occupation = |years_active= |spouse = |partner = |parents = |children = 3 |relatives = |website = |known_for = [[Almost Live!]] |awards = }} '''John Keister''' (born February 15, 1956) is a [[Seattle]]-based comedian, writer, commentator and motivational speaker, best known as the host of the local comedy program ''[[Almost Live!]]'' from 1988 to 1999. A native of Seattle, he grew up in the [[Seward Park, Seattle, Washington|Seward Park]] neighborhood and graduated from [[Franklin High School (Washington)|Franklin High School]] in 1974. He was an editor for ''[[The Daily of the University of Washington|The Daily]]'' as a student at the [[University of Washington]], graduating with a degree in communications in 1979. He wrote for ''[[The Rocket (newspaper)|The Rocket]]'' and initially joined [[KING-TV]] as a music reviewer on a program called ''REV'' in 1984. Shortly thereafter, he joined the cast of KING's local comedy program [[Almost Live!]]. Following the departure of original host [[Ross Shafer]], Keister became the show's host and its format was reworked to emphasize the opening monologue, sketches, and parody news segments. He won a total of twelve local [[Emmy Awards]] for his work on the show. ''Almost Live!'' was canceled by KING in 1999. In 2000, Keister created a new sketch comedy show for competing station [[KIRO-TV]], titled ''[[The John Report with Bob]]''. Its format was similar to the news report segment he had done on ''Almost Live!'', with additional sketch material from [[Bob Nelson (Almost Live!)|Bob Nelson]] and local comedy troupes. The new show was canceled after a year. Keister was a writer for the 2005 public television series ''[[The Eyes of Nye]]'', starring fellow ''Almost Live!'' alumnus [[Bill Nye]]. Keister currently teaches Video Production classes at The Art Institute of Seattle.Art Institute of Seattle. "[http://www.artinstitutes.edu/seattle/academics_faculty.asp AIS Faculty]" ''[[The Art Institute of Seattle Faculty]]''. He has three sons, Elroy, Riley, and Arlo. Keister is also a staff writer and producer for the critically acclaimed children's PBS series [[Biz Kid$|Bizkid$]] taped at Seattle's KCTS public television studios. He shows up occasionally in several of the series short vignettes playing various funny characters. On April 30, 2009, Keister appeared on ''The Brandon Ivey Show'' at the Historic University Theater in the U-District. He refuted rumors regarding his death. Also in 2009, Keister was the narrator for ''[[Sonicsgate]]'', a documentary about the [[Seattle SuperSonics relocation to Oklahoma City|controversial relocation]] of the [[Seattle SuperSonics]] to [[Oklahoma City Thunder|Oklahoma City]]. In January 2013, Keister returned to KING-TV with a new comedy show called ''[[The 206]]'', along with former ''Almost Live!'' costar [[Pat Cashman]] and his son [[Chris Cashman|Chris]].{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldnet.com/article/20130104/ENT/701049858|title='Almost Live' crew returns with 'The 206'|publisher=[[Daily Herald (Everett)|Everett Daily Herald]]|date=2013-01-04}} In October, 2014, The 206 co-host Pat Cashman announced that Keister had departed the show to pursue other interests. When contacted by the Seattle Times, Keister explained that he was happy that he was able to help get ''The 206'' up and running, "but everyone is working for almost nothing." He said at the time that he was putting together a one-man show called "The Keister Monologues".{{cite web|url=http://seattletimes.com/html/nicolebrodeur/2024888231_nicolenames28xml.html|title=Don’t panic: We found John Keister|publisher=[[Seattle Times]]|date=2014-10-27}} In September 2017 Keister gave what he called his last stand-up performances in Seattle at [[Benaroya Hall]]. The show was entitled "Living and Dying in Seattle".[http://www.seattletimes.com/entertainment/nightlife/john-keisters-last-stand-almost-live-star-straddles-old-and-new-seattle/ John Keister’s last stand: ‘Almost Live!’ star straddles old and new Seattle]. ''[[Seattle Times]]'', August 25, 2017. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb name|0445178|name=John Keister}} *[http://www.miscmedia.com/2001/04/17/no-keister-puns/ No 'Keister' Puns] (on the cancellation of ''The John Report with Bob'') *http://www.bizkids.com *[http://the206.tv The (206)] official site {{DEFAULTSORT:Keister, John}} [[Category:1956 births]] [[Category:American male comedians]] [[Category:American comedians]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Writers from Seattle]] [[Category:University of Washington alumni]]
